div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

Ces pierres sont divisees en lots de 20 a 100 m. 3.

Les scheteurs devront payer le droit d'enchere de 1 % et deposer le 10 % de la valeur de la marchandise achetee au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement integral a la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjundicaton.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager- R. SMELLING
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
TUESDAY, MAY 21, 1907.

div.head: SCENES FROM AL JABARTI.
div.p: Since the leaders of the Egyptian Nationalist party are never tired of insisting that the sufferings of Egypt in the past have been grossly and wittingly exaggerated by the partisans of the British Occupation, the critic who is ignorant of Egyptian history is faced by a difficulty, viz, that he has little information on which to base any reply he may wish to make to the 'patriotic' "laudator temporis acti." For the reign of Ismail Pasha documents exist, but what if the champions of the Nation alist idea declare that Ismail's rule was something exceptional and that if would he in the highest degree unfair to take the oppression and injustice that marked the latter days of that ruler as being the normal feature of Egyptian history during the past century? But there is evidence, and evidence of a very remarkable nature concerning the sufferings of the Egyptians in earlier days, and among the witnesses we shall cite the talented Sheikh Abderrahman Al Jabarti, the only great Egyptian author of the past century, a Moslem and something of a scholar, neither an 'intrus' nor xenophobe—indeed a very credit able example of a pious and conservative Moslem. For the edification of our readers and the benefit of the critics above-mentioned, we purpose to give certain extracts from Al Jabarti's VIIth volume, wherein the good Sheikh describes the great events that followed the withdrawal of the French from Egypt and the return of the Turkish armies under the command of the Vizier Yusuf Pasha, We will begin with the 20th day of the month Saffar A.II. 1260. On that day Turkish soldiers, horsemen and footmen, reached the city of Cairo and the Grand Vizier pitched his camp at Shubra. The French garrison under General Belliard—unable to risk further action against the combined force of the English, the Turks and the Mamelukes — made honourable terms for itself. The negotiations were rapidly completed and on Thursday, the 30th of the month, the French retired from the capital while the Osmanli soldiers entered first through a breach in the walls and later through the Bah el Nasr. Great was the exultation of the inhabitants as the new-comers marched through the streets. Men and boys cried "Allah yinsar el Sultan"—'God give victory to the Sultan and the women uttered the 'zaghareet' from the windows. The redoubtable janissaries piled their arms and placed their ensigns before the cafes, the shops and the baths, while Yusif Pasha, accompanied by agas and soldiers, rode to the Mosque of Hussein and gave thanks for victory. Then the Osmauli General paid a brief visit, to the Sheikh el Sadat, examined the Masque of Al Azhar, where he gave largesse to the ferrashes and the servants, and returned to his camp. Meanwhile the janissaries trooped into the town amid the cheers of the populace; but the merchant and shopkeepers, before whose establishments the soldiers piled their muskets, regarded these wild warriors with some concern and in the afternoon the allies of the Egyptians obliged the townspeople to furnish them with rations, water, "and even coffee" according to our author. Next day "Kaba Kol" the leader of the janissaries :—whose strange name suggests some wild Tartar from the interior of Asia Minor—ordered his men to take down the banners that had been planted before the shops and the merchants had a temporary respite. On Sunday, the first day of the month Rabi el Awal, the grand Aga of the janissaries, rode through the streets and on the following day another potent dignitary, Hassein the Kapitan Pasha, reached Gizeh. Thence he repaired to the mosque of Sheikh Hussein where he sacrificed five buffaloes and seven sheep and laid four Persian shawls on the Sheikh's tomb. But while the Osmanli notables behaved as victorious notables should behave, the army was showing signs of a certain lack of discipline. In the Gamalieh quarter a thirsty him, hade him pay the money and reprimanding him severely, called for the bastinado. But the Arnaout so far from submitting to the penalty drew his pistol from his sash and laid the Aga low, and hastening to his house maintained an accurate fire on all who approached to arrest him. Five persons had fallen when two of his fellow countrymen passed by; the janissaries seeing a foe in every mountaineer slew them both and when their attack on the house proved costly and useless, set fire to it The soldier broke out but was overpowered and executed and thus, "nine persons perished for a few drops of liquorice water." But these incidents were forgotten by the populace in the joy of the solemn and triumphal entry of the armies of the Khalif. On the fifth of the month the vanguard of the Osmanli army passed through the Bab el Nasr and from dawn to midday the great host marched through the streets. The Albanian hillmen, the Mameluke Emirs, the Turks, the Syrian infantry, the janissaries and the marines, great officers of the Empire, Ibrahim Pasha the wali of Aleppo, Hamed Pasha wali of Egypt, the Katkhoda of the Empire, Jibji Pasha Toussoun, the Cadi of the army and his naibs, the ulema and the orders of dervishes marched past to the sound of drums and horns, and behind them rode the Vizier Yussef Pasha clothed in blue pelisse embroidered with gold and lined with martens fur, and wearing a white aigrette adorned with diamonds ; behind him walked two of his followers who cast largesse—silver coins minted at Stamboul among the crowd. What wonder that Al Jabarti wrote on that day—"Praise and glory to God who has granted us this blessing." The next few days passed happily, but on the 18th of the month the Vizier deprived the Grand Cadi of his office on account of "his revolting avarice". On the 24th came a tragedy. The daughter of Sheikh El Bakri, accused of misconduct with a Frenchman was arrested, a shameful breach of the 13th article of the Convention signed by the Turks, British and French. Her professions of repentance were in vain. Her father disavowed her and her head was struck from her shoulders. Another erring lady was strangled by her husband with the permission of the Grand Vizier. Now, too, the troops began to rob right and left and those quartered in the Christian kisms charged their hosts double as much as they demanded trom the Moslems for food, pocket money and Turkish baths. On the third day of the next month orders were given to treat Christians and Jews with humanity and on the 14th the town criers informed Cairo that all who believed in a Holy Book were guaranteed peace and security—if they would pay a small contribution equal to four years' taxation to their rulers. But these contributions did not find their way to the pockets of the army. As in the Yemen today, so in Egypt more than a century ago, the Ottoman troops were unpaid and looting and violence on their part grew more and more frequent. Cruel and unjustifiable executions, forced loans, and attacks on peace able citizens became the order of the day. "A soldier would sit down in,a shop and the, would arise and swear that his purse had been stolen and lay hands on whatever he could take to indemnify himself. The troops, moreover, compelled the people to give them good coins in exchange for counterfeit pieces They insulted women in the streets in shameless fashion and in the villages they committed every sort of excess. When they entered any village they would produce a paper on which Turkish words were written, and would tell the fellaheen that they had come to make an end of tyranny or any other invention that come into their travelling expenses after which they would arrest the Sheikhs and e.xtort large contributions from them Consequently most of the Egyptian—especially of the fellaheen regretted the days of the French occupation." While their deliverers played these prank near Cairo the leading Egyptian Emir, the Mameluke Al Alfi, gave the Saides cause for complaint. On hearing of the death of any person, this ingenious financier would seize the rightful heirs and by beating and imprisoning them seldom failed to persuade these unfortunates to make him sole legatee His agents terrified women and children and carried houses by storm in such fashion that the Saides, preferring the intermittent ferocity of the Turks to the constant oppression of the Emir, repaired to Cairo where they thronged the streets and the gardens and lived by theft, or from the alms of the charitably disposed." Such was the condition of Egypt three months after its delivery from the French occupation Absit omen !

div.head: A Notable Success
div.p: A young Egyptian lady, of the name of Nabawieh -Moussah, has passed the baccalaureat.

div.head: Lecture on Egypt
div.p: Mr J. M. Robertson, M. P., lectured on the " Problem of Egypt " in South Place Chapel, London, on Sunday last.

div.head: Alexandria-Beyrout
div.p: The Florin Rubattino Company will begin their new express service between Alexandria and Beyrout on the 29th inst. The journey will be made in twenty four hours.

div.head: Cairo Scientific Society
div.p: The next meeting of the Cairo Scientific Society will be held at the school of Medicine on Thursday at 4.30 p.m., when Mr. P. S. Barlow will lead a paper on "Modern theories and problems of solution."

div.head: New Medical Licsences
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has licensed Dr. Ernesto Ferrari and Dr. Charalambo T. Polyehroniadis to practise as medical men in Egypt, and Mr. Dimitriaki Tavoularis to practise as a pharmacist.

div.head: Accident at a Mosque
div.p: The ceiling of the mosque Sidi Mohamed El Eraki in the Mousky fell in last Sunday while several natives were saying their prayers. Fortunately only one of them, a certain Mohamed Deif, was slightly injured.

div.head: Ras El Bar
div.p: Mohamed Bey El Chazily, Governor of Damietta, arrived last Sunday at Cairo where he had an interview with the Minister of the Interior in order to submit the plan of the bathing establishment to be erected this year on the sea shore at Ras el-Bar.

div.head: The Census
div.p: " AL Garida " calls attention to the fact that many houses of Egyptians in Cairo were not visited for the purpose of taking the census. The same journal points out that if this negligence characterised the methods of obtaining returns in other parts of the country, the statistics now published are worthless.

div.head: A Cairo Scandal
div.p: The wife of a well known commercial man in Cairo went off with a music-hall artist by the S.S. Niger on the 3rd inst. The lady took with her jewels to the value of about thirty thousand pounds. The husband complained to the police, who arrested the couple on the arrival of the steamer at Marseilles.

div.head: The Cairo Theatres
div.p: A commission composed of two delegates from the Public Works Department and one delegate from the police has been apointed to examine the condition of the Cairo theatres for public safety. In the case of the Abbas theatre the commission has decided to increase the windows and exits. All the other theatres in Cairo will be examined in turn with a view to deciding what precautions should be taken.

div.head: A Reminiscence from Egypt
div.p: Lieutenant Boyd Alexander described to a meeting of the Royal Geographical Society last week the experiences of his expedition across Africa from the Niger to the Nile. A curious incident which he witnessed was a Hausa wrestling-match in the Graeco-Roman style, which was probably introduced from Egypt by the Hausas after the Roman occupation.

div.head: Education in the Sudan
div.p: Mr. Currie has been on an inspection tour to Kassala Province. He was much pleased with the progress of the pupils both at the industrial and at the primary schools. Thirteen boys were promoted from the primary to the technical school, with the full consent of their parents, who were very favourably impressed by Mr. Currie. Mr. Hewison, Director of the Agriculture and Lands Department, has also been on a visit to that province.

div.head: The British Club
div.p: Another concert was given at the British Club Alexandria, on Saturday last, (which will be the final one for this season,) when a good programme was gone through as follows :- Pianoforte solo, " Oberon " Miss Cohn ; Song, " Glorious Devon " Mr. J. L Tullock ; Violin & Pianoforte duet, (a) " Cavatina (b) " Morris Dance " Miss Bell and Mr Gilmour ; Comic song, " Inquisitive Kiddie and encore Queer Questions " Mr. C.H Nichols ; song " A Spring song " Mr. J. B, Clarke ; song " To the Front " Mr. H. Sheldlrick song "'I'm the softest o' the family ' Mr Mitchell ; Pianoforte solos, " Qui Vive " and encore, Miss Cohu : Hong,, " The Deathless A Army" and encore Mr. J. L Tullock ; Violin & Pianoforte duet, " Fantasia Air from Maritana " Miss Bell and Mr. Gilmour ; Song " She is ma daisy " and encore " We parted on the shore " Mr. J. Mitchell ; Hong, "Selected " Mr. J. B. Clarke ; Comic so " Adverts " and encore "He was a married man " Mr. C H. Nicholls ; Song, " The Deep Blue Wave " . Mr. H. Sheldrick. Mrs., W. F. Satfjeant Miss B. Cohu, and Mrs. Harold Sheldrick kindly acted as accompanists. The entertainment committe of the British Club are to be congratulated on the success which has attended their efforts during the season. just ended. The concerts have been greatly appreciated by all those who attended them, and a resumption next autumn will be eagerly looked forward to.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RETURN
div.p: MEETING IN LONDON.

The Earl of Cromer called at the Foreign Office last Tuesday afternoon formally to report himself, and to see Sir Edward Grey and thr various departmental officials. His lordship, who has borne the journey home very satisfactorily, looked fairly well, and is already improving in health.

Sir E. Grey warmly greeted Lord Cromer, with whom he discussed for about half an hour the present situation in Egypt. His lordship will remain in London for a time, and his expert advice will be available should the state of Egyptian affairs necessitate further consultation with him.
Amongst those present to offer an early welcome home to the great administrator of Egypt yesterday week were :

Viscount Althorp (Lord Chamberlain, representing his Majesty the King), the Prime Minister, the Marquis of Ripon, Field-Marshal Bail Roberts, the Earl of Halsbury, Lord Tweedmouth, Sir Edward Grey, the Manquis of Lansdowne, the Earl of Crewe, the Duke of Norfolk, Count Gleichen, Lord Fitzmaurice, the Marquis and Marchioness of Bath, Earl Carrington, Sir Claude. MacDonald (British. Ambassador at Tokio), Admiral Lord Charles Beresford, the Earl of Kenmare, Lord Sanderson, Viscount Errington (Lord Cromer's eldest son). Lord Edward Cecil, General Sir John Ardagh, Sir E. Bradford, the Hon. Derek Keppel, the Hon. Arthur Stanley, M.P., Lord Demnan, Lord Revelstoke, Princess Victor of

Hohenlobe, the Dowager Marchioness of Bath, Sir Charles Hardinge, Sir Eric Barrington, Brigadier General Sir John Maxwell, Mr. Thomas Baring, Captain Baring, the Hop. div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive, who is still at Mariout, will return to Montazah tomorrow.
The Khedive is leaving Alexandria Mahroussa on the 7th inst. for Constantinople His Highness will be accompanied by Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan.

div.head: THE MINISTERS
div.p: At their last meeting the Council of Ministers appointed Mazloum Pasha. Minister of Finance, to take the place of Fouad Pasha, as Minister of Justice during the latter's absence.
Abani Pasha, Minister of War, will take the place of Saul Pasha Zagloul, as Minister of Public Instruction during the latter's absence.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISTS.
div.p: Our amusing contemporary, the "Egyptian Standard," informs us in its issue of yesterday, the 20th inst., No. 65, Page 1. Col. II. line 29 that the deeds and words of the Egyptian Nationalists have but one object "The hastening of the moral degeneration of their countrymen." We always were suspicious of some our Nationalists, hut it is indeed hard to be given away by one's friends.

div.head: PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT.
div.p: By order of a Ministerial Decree, dated 14th instant, Mohamed Zaher Bey, "chief engineer of the 1st class, attached to the first circle of irrigation and Moussa Bey Ghaleh, director of the teftish of El Wadi, have been admitted to the pension list as from the 10th April last

div.head: BACTERIOLOGICAL department.
div.p: The Department of Public Health have decided to appoint an assistant director to the Bacteriological Department. A native doctor will be appointed and will be required to pass one year of study in Europe prior to taking up the new appointment.

div.head: OFFICIAL DENIAL.
div.p: The Ministry the Interior offically deny the truth of the statements recently made in several of the native newspapers in reference to the capture by brigands of a notable business man at Damanhour. It was further in correctly reported that the brigands were negociating with the prisoner's brother for his release against payment of BE. 500 by way of ransom.

div.head: PLAGUE
div.p: One death in hospital is reported from Benha ; one death in hospital at Beni Mazar ; three cases and one death in hospital at Samallout ; one death in hospital at Assiout ; one fresh case and one death outside hospital at Abnoub ; one case is reported as cured at Deirout ; one death has occurred in hospital at Esneh.

div.head: CAIRO DRAIN SCHEME
div.p: MR. JAMES INTERVIEWED.

As there have been a very large number of conflicting and unauthorised statements in the Press on this subject the "Egyptian Gazette" representative made a point of interviewing Mr. Carkeet James at the Public Works office yesterday. . '

Our representative gathered that all that has hitherto been published is entirely erroneous, and, as a matter of fact nothing whatever has been definitely decided; nor has any official communication been made on the subject of the drainage scheme of' the capital.

In brief the actual situation is as follows Of nine schemes submitted, one has been selected and the Adviser fo the Ministry of Public Works Sir William Garstin, is at present engaged in preparing his note on the scheme before presenting it to the Council or Ministers.

This is a very bald announcement, but it is all that is justified at the present moment. The amount of work entailed in arriving at this stage only must have been stupendous, including, as it has «lone, a most minute and systematic examination of the city and an enormous amount of work making plans and designs. All this work has been beset with difficulties, not the least of which has been the lack of good draughtsmen. One by one all obstacles have been overcome, however, and in a very short time the perfected scheme will be made public.

It is already generally known that Mr. Carkeet James was for eighteen years in India, from whence he was called to tackle the vital question of Cairo drainage. Mr. James has already accumulated a large staff of draughtsmen the most important factors - and a band of assistants, animated with the same energy as their chief, not to mention a large sense of courtesy not always met with in Government Departments.
We give very full particulars on this subject so soon as the scheme shall have been approved by the Council of Ministers.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
div.p: Some incontrovertible figures are at hand to show how purely local is the present financial crisis, which is only confined to Alexandria and Cairo. For example the receipts of the Egyptian Railway Administration are lose on twenty per cent higher than they were last year. The receipts of the Delta Light Railways are also a good indication of the prosperous state of the country. Up to date the receipts of this company are twenty-five per cent higher than for the corresponding period last year. The receipts of the Egyptian. Markets are very satisfactory and every things tends to show that the prosperity of the country was never at a higher level. The same tale is told of all the other companies whose operations lie in the villages. The fellaheen have not been affected in the slightest degree by the present slump.
The Alexandria and Cairo Bourses were worse than ever this morning and owing to the forced sales some of the soundest shares show a decline.

div.head: CATTLE MARKETS CLOSED
div.p: In consequence of the recrudescence of cattle plague the Government have decided to close the cattle markets of Assiont, Ghizeh, Fayoum, and Wasta. Cattle can only he brought into Cairo after having passed through quarantine at Ghizeh.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: L'orchesfre Bracale dont'les débuts ont eu lien dimanche, a retrouvé son succes de chaque anuee aupres des nombreux habitures de San Stefano.

Nous sommes informés d'autre part de l'en gagement du celebre violoniste Scrato, par la Direction du Casino : il se fera entendre, unefois par semaine, Je soir, «fans la nouvelle Salle des Fétes, avee accompagnement de grand orchestre sons la direction de M. Bracale, Voilà qui nous promet de belles soirées en perspective.
Prochainement ler grami concert, vocal dans lequel se feront entendre 5 artistes des principaux théâtre d'Italie spécialement engagés et dont on dit le plus grand bien.
Ainsi quil a été déjà annoncé, chaque après midi à 5 h. Concert symphonique et chaque soir concert pendant le diner.

Le bal de samedi soir a obtenu le plus grand sucees et tout ce qu'Alexandrie compte de notabilités se trouvait là réuni pour cette brìi lante fête d'ouverture : plus de 300 personnes se pressaient au Restaurant.

Les constructions- nouvelles ont rencontre l'approbation et disons le mot, l'admiration de tous ; On s'est plus a admirer les vastes proportions et le bel ageùcement des nouvatux salons, ferrasses et veramlalis, et ce fut un concert' del louanges à l'adresse de l'architecte Stienon autour des plans et qui, en un laps de temps si court a su mener à bonne fin de si importants travaux.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: Tne Moss liner Seti, now on berth, will sail for Liverpool about Saturday June 15.
The Moss liner Menes sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool via Malta with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: THE CROMER MEMORIAL
We do no hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits— free discussion:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

Dear Sir,—I have read with interest the letter from "Anxious Observer" published in your issue of the 18th inst. In discussing the question of a large Cromer Memorial Tuberculosis Hospital with various friends well acquainted with tips country, I find that practically all agree that there are many great objections to such a scheme.

To begin with, any one who knows the native mind will at once confirm the statement that if intended to benefit them, the money will be practically wasted. They will not go into a home or hospital of this sort, and as far as they are concerned, it would undoubtedly be another
case of "wasted effort."

The idea is not popular, as far as I can discover, among any class of the community, and it is very difficult to imagine whom it is going to benefit? especially as, I believe, a similar undertaking on a modest scale is already being developed, and has reached a stage which renders its final accomplishment probable. This, I understand, is ample to meet any possible demand.

The vast and increasing need of a Maternity Home, however, must be patent to all. The small institution, which has been quietly doing what good work was possible in this line for some years, is cramped for funds, and only in a position to touch the fringe of the demand.

If absorbed into a large scheme of a "Cromer International Maternity Home," its sphere of usefulness would be indefinitely enlarged, and any one helping the work would feel that they were assisting to fulfill Lord and Lady Cromer's farewell wishes, as set forth in the former's valedictory address.

Given the necessary support, a suitable building, worthy of the. name it would bear, could be erected on some suitable spot in Alexandria, and there is no reason to doubt that it would prove a lasting blessing to the classes (native and European alike), who are unable, in those times of trouble, to obtain the assistance, of which they stand in need

The présent home has already a sum of £2,000, raised by voluntary contributions, which could doubtless be made available, with the donors' consent, as a nucleus for the larger scheme, and the increased publicity which would be obtained, would doubtless attract the annual subscriptions of many who know nothing of the present modest little charity.

In conclusion, whilst apologizing for troubling you at such length, may I ask you to offer the hospitality of your columns for the expression of the opinions of others on this subject, And if a sufficient response should be received, it would be easy to carry the matter a stage further in due course.—Your faithfully,
FRANCIS ALLEN.
Alexandria,

div.head: THE CHATHAM ACCIDENT.
div.p: CLAN CUMMING'S LIABILITIES

In the Admiralty Court last week Mr. Justice Bucknill had before him an Action brought by the owners of the steamship Clan Cumming (of the Clan Line) to limit their liability in respect of damages arising out of the collision between the Clan Cumming and the London steamship Chatham in the Suez Canal on September 5, 1905. As a result of the impact the Chatham took fire, and she was sunk, it being feared that the flames would reach her cargo of explosives. In consequence of tho hindrance to traffic in the channel she was subsequently blown up by order of the Canal authorities. The owners of the Chatham brought a claim for damages against the owners of the Clan Cumming, and there was a counter-claim, each party alleging negligence on the other side. The case was heard before the President (Sir Gorell Barnes) who held that the Clan Cumming was alone to blame for the collision This decision wan subsequently confirmed by the Court of Appeal There was no loss of life or personal injury as the result of the collision. The owners of the Clan Cumming feared, that the claims against thorn in respect of loss of ship and goods would exceed their statutory liability of £8 per ten on the gross registered tonnage (after deduction for crew space) of the Clan Cumming. They therefore brought this action to limit their liability; and they offered to pay into court the sum of £37,533 10s. (being the aggregate of £8 per ton), together with interest at the rate of 4 per cent, from the date of the collision His Lordship made tho usual decree, limiting the plaintiffs' liability as prayed.

div.head: THE HAVAS AGENCY
div.p: Last Thursday the Havas Agency sent the following telegram to the local newspapers :— "Une bombe a écliité à Pontelagoscuro un pen avant le passage du train royal. L'auteur de l'attentat a été arrêté."

An Italian Society at Alexandria telegraphed to their Sovereign at Rome in order to congratulate the King oil having escaped. The following telegraphic reply was received: Newsdevoid of any foundation. Our Sovereign, gratified for your attention, however, thanks you all the same.
A Cairo contemporary remarks :-

C'est encore un nouvel exemple a ajouter à tant d'autres de la conscience que certaines agences apportent aux renseignements qu'elles nous font cependant payer assez cher pour que le public soit informé exactement de ce qui se passe en Europe.
Que youlez vous ? nouvelles fausses, ou informations dénuées de toute compréhension. Nous commençons à y être habituées.

div.head: BRITISH CONSULS IN EGYPT.
div.p: THEIR COMMERICAL EXPERIENCE

Mr. J. Robertson asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs last Tuesday whether any of the British Consuls in Egypt had been appointed to such posts by reason of their commercial and industrial experience ; and whether, if not, he would, in order to assist British subjects in meeting the severe and increasing competition in that country, replace the present Consuls by others possessing the requisite experience, or, alternatively, would appoint commercial and industrial experts to British Consulates in Egypt.

Sir E. Grey ; There are two British Consuls, one with the local, the other with the per sonal, rank of Consul-General, in Egypt, apart from Sir Eldon Gorst. Both of these Consuls are officers of long and thorough experience in all the duties, including the commercial duties discharged by their service in Oriental countries, and no reflection has been cast upon their present posts, which they have held for some years. There is; therefore, no reason for making any change at present of Consular officers in Egypt. There are, in addition, two Vice Consuls in Egypt. Consular posts in Egypt are usually filled from the Levant service, entrance to which is obtained by open competition. With regard to the suggestion that commercial and industrial experts should be chosen outside the service, I must point out that there is no more reason for doing this as regards Egypt than there is in the case of other industrial countries. The best we can do is to get men who have some commericial knowledge to enter for the Consular service, to give them some training at the Board of Trade before beginning their duties abroad, and to encourage the study of commercial matters afterwards.

div.head: THE HEDJAZ RAILWAYS
div.p: Beyrout, Friday.

Au official note declares that the authorities at. Damascus have bought 76 camels for the reinforcement of the Camel Corps guarding the Hamidieh-Hedjaz railway 25 of these trained camels will he added in the immediate service of the above mentioned corps, while fifty with their riders are to be despatched to the neighbourhood of Medina to guard the telegraph line and the repairs undertaken thereon.

Kazim Pasha, head commissioner and inspector of the construction and exploitation works of the Hamidieh railway, has, after a trip of inspection along the line, returned to Damascus. The Pasha sent the following despatch on the 14th of April to the Prime Minister and the High Commission of the Hamidieh-Hedjaz line at Constantinople.

"I beg to state that according to the telegram received from the engineer of the Medina section the company of Imperial troops working on that, section has accomplished in the first half of the current mouth 832 cubic metres of rock extraction and 2,094 cubic metres of earth embankment. The total work achieved since the start up to date amounts to 24,389 cubic metres of earth embankment and rock excavation."

The sheikh of the Prophet shrine at edina advises the departure from that town of Zeid Effendi, the leading merchant of those regioins accompanied by a caravan of 57 persons with the object of witnessing the great works of the Hamidieh-Hedjaz railway. If is further stated that another large caravan will follow this one shortly, and already preparations have been made for their conveyance in all comfort to Damascus.

div.head: Oil Field Discovered.
div.p: An oil field is reported to have been discovered in the property of the wealthy land-owner and cotton manufacturer, Mr. Athanas Trypank in Mersyne district. The chemical examination of the petrol is said to have shown that it is superior to that of the Baku Wells.

div.head: FLIGHT ON A DREDGER
div.p: Suez, Sunday.

Following up a dispute on the Suez Canal dredger No. 6, stationed near Kilometre 133 in the Canal, the captain of the dredger, of French nationality, yesterday afternoon stabbed three times a sailor, named Casulis and a native of Cyprus; and subsequently took refuge in his cabin, where he locked himself up, armed with a revolver.

The news was at once telegraphed to the Canal Company at Port Tewfik from the station, while the victim was placed on board the D.O.A. mailboat, which was passing at the time, and landed at Suez, and shortly after was conveyed to the French Hospital, where he is progressing favorably, as the wounds inflicted seem to be slight.

At 4 p.m. the French Consul, Mr. E Altemer, with Mr do Turris, Chief of the Police, and other Suez Canal officials, proceeded-to the spot by a steam launch and arrested the captain of the dredger who was taken to Suez for the preliminary trial.

div.head: EUROPEAN FOUND DEAD.
div.p: A European was found last night at 8 p.m. killed on the railway line at Arbain station. It is presumed that he was killed by jumping from the train, as his head was completely smashed. The man has not yet been identified, and is believed to be a stranger.

div.head: SLATIN PASHA
div.p: Yesterday morning, per the S.S. Kosseir, the Inspector General of the Sudan, Sir Rudolph Von Slatin Pasha K.C.M.G., C.B., landed at Suez, coming from Port Sudan.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mohamed Ali has arrived in Paris
from Constantinople.
Prince Joachim Albert of Prussia is expected to arrive at Port Said tomorrow by the German East African S.S. Feldmarshall from South Africa.
The Sirdar will leave Erkoweit on the 26th inst. to return to Khartoum.
It is said that Saad Pasha Zaghloul, the Minister of Public Instruction, intends paying a visit to England this summer.

Count von Berandorff, the German Minister, and Mr. Wegener, secretary to the German Agency, are arriving at San Stefano on Saturday next and from the 25th inst. the German Diplomatic Agency will be at San Stefano for the summer season.
Boron Max Oppenheim, of the German Agency Cairo, leaves Egypt tomorrow for Germany.
Mr. and Mrs. George Royle are leaving Port Said by the P. and O. S.S. Victoria on the 28th inst. for Marseilles and thence to Switzerland.

Mr. E. J. Scott, after more than two years' consecutive work as secretary of the local board of the Corporation of Western Egypt, Ltd., is leaving for England to-day by the P. and 0. S.S. Arabia. Mr. Scott is relieved by Mr. W. C. Scales, formerly secretary of the Oasis Syndicate, now wound up.

div.head: SINAITIC INSCRIPTIONS AT THE BRITISH MUSEUM
div.p: There have just been placed on exhibition in the Egyptian galleries of the British Museum a select few of the Egyptian inscriptions recently discovered in the Sinaitic peninsula. One of the most interesting is a sandstone stele and altar set up by Sebek-her-heb, an overseer of the Royal apartments, and a subordinate official named Kemen, who were attached to the Royal Chancery. The tablet, which is dated in the forty-fourth year of Amenem hat III, about B. C. 2300, is of red sandstone, and contains an inscription in which a prayer is offered to Athor, the " lady of the turquoise land, " by which name the Sinaitic peninsula was known to the Ancient Egyptians. There is also the lower portion of a statue of Usertesen II., B. C. 2333, dedicated to Hathor by the King's officials stationed in Sinai, and the lower portion of a seated figure of Hathor, dedicated to the goddess by Senefru, a captain of the boats in the reign of Amen-em hat I. The objects were discovered at Serabit-el-Kadim, in the Sinaitic peninsula, and were presented to the British Museum by the Egypt Exploration Fund.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd hui midi et demie).
Les cours de nos principales valeurs fléchissent encore sur des réalisations forcées.

La déconfiture de deux importantes maisons de commerce, fortement engagées en titres, a causé ici une certaine émotion. La Bourse Khédiviale d'Alexandrie et la National Bank perdent, en une seule séance, 1/2 livre, l'Agricole 1/4 de livre à 8 1/4 5/16, la Béhéra une livre à 32. La Salt and Soda recule de 9 pence à 181, les Cotton Mills de 3 pence à 4/6, les lots Turcs et la Banque d'Odent de 1 franc à 154 et. 123 respectivement, L'Union foncière fléchit à û 1/16 sans affaires et le Crédit franco-Egyptien à 5 l|4, 1|I6 ; La Banque d'Athènes est faible, à 125 1/2, l'obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier Egyptien réactionne à 324 et la nouvelle à 268. Par contre les actions des Eaux du Caire remontent d'un franc à 114 ot les Splendid de 1/16 à 4 11/16.
On a traité hors corbeille plusieurs valeurs, soumises aux cours du " moratorium, " a des prix sensiblement inférieurs a ceux de la cote offioielle.
On a échangé notomment 2,000 actions de la Karam à 9/16.

div.head: REGLEMENTATION DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Voici quelques-unes des dispositions qui seront soumises par le Comité à l'Association des Courtiers en Valeurs d'Alexandrie, à rassemblée générale ordinaire qui se tiendra ce soir à 4 heures.
"Le remisier, simple intermédiaire entre son client et les agents, ne pourra faire exécuter les ordres dont il est chargé que par l'agent auquel il sera attaché ou les fondés de pouvoir de cet agent.
En aucun cas il no pourra exécuter lui même ces ordres.

En cas de contravention, l'agent auquel leremisier est attaché, ainsi que la contre partie, seront frappés chacun d'une amende de L.E. 5 et l'affaire sera considérée comme nulle. Le dit remisier sera rayé.
Les affaires à terme, achat et vente, ne peuvent être traitées que pour la quinzaine en cours. Le Comité fixera les jours de liquidation de chaque quinzaine.
Les affaires pour la quinzaine suivante ne peuvent être traitées qu a partir du jour que le Comité fixera pour le report.
Lo Comité est autorisé à suspendre le marché à terme chaque fois qu'il le croira utile aux intérêts de la place.
Il a les pouvoirs les plus étendus pour pro céder d'offiee, s'il le juge nécessaire, à une organisation spéciale du dit marché à terme.

Les titres des Sociétés étrangères de la va leur de £4 au moins, peuvent être livrés avant la libération définitive, mais à condition que lo transfert soit régulier. Les acheteurs sont te nus de prendre livraison des quantités qui leur sont présentées à valoir sur leurs achats.

Tout agent qui inciterait à la spéculation ou favoriserait la spéculation de l'employé de l'un de ses collègues, sera frappé la première fois d'une amende de L.E. 50. En cas de récidive, il pourra être rayé par décision du Comité.

div.head: SERVICE MARITIME ROUMAIN
div.p: Faisant suite à la demande de plusieurs familles d'Egypte, passant lasaisen estivale à Rhodes, de faire eeeale encore uno fois dans cette île, il est porté à la connaissance du public que le paquebot-poste "Imperatul Traian" touchera do nouveau l'île de Rhodes, dans son voyage do départ d'Alexandrie, soit le vendredi 7 Juin a.c. à 4 heures de l'après-midi.
Cette escale aura lieu en tant qu'aucune prohibition quarnntenaire ne serait jusqu'alors dictée par les autorités sanitaires de l'Empire Ottoman, contre les provenences d'Egypte.

div.head:
THE ATTEMPT' ON THE TSAR.
THE DUMA'S RESOLUTION.

div.p: M. Stolypin revealed to the Duma the arrest

of 28 revolutionaries who, it is alleged, plotted to enter the palace and assassinate the Tsar, as well as the Grand Duke Nicholas and the Premier. The Duma passed a resolution expressing joy at the escape of the Tsar and indignation at the plot.
The labourites and socialists absented themselves. (Reuter)
The Duma, considering the ministerial de clarations, voted an "ordre du jour" expressing indignation against the criminals and its joy at knowing that the Tsar was safe. (Havas)

div.head:
SOUTH MANCHURIA RAILWAYS.
AMERICA GETS ORDER.

div.p: Japan has placed orders with America to the extent of 12,000,000 dollars for the equipment of the South Manchuria railways. High prices have been paid to ensure rapid delivery. (R.)

An enormous demonstration was held here owing to the stagnation in the wine trade which is attributed to foreign adulteration. 60,000 people arrived from the surrounding districts. The demonstration passed off quietly. (Reuter)
On the occasion of the visit of members of the Marseilles Municipality, cordial toasts were exchanged and telegrams addressed to M. Fallieres and King Victor Emmanuel. (1l.)
M. Clemencean said that the Government,
assisted by the majority, would repress the troubles and particularly. the anti-military troubles. (Havas)
M. Fallieres was present at the banquet of the General Council at Lyons and returned to Paris in the evening. (Havas)
The Japanese cruisers (Chitojse and Tsukube have left for Germany.

div.head: FROM THE OLD MOKATTAMS.
div.p: There is always pleasure to be found roaming upon the hills, and how beautiful it is just now on the old brown Mokattamps, for it is near evening, and the sun glorious as it has been all the day is about to disappear into the bosom of the desert Free and unfettered we can delight in the joys which solitude offers, and unhidden to the mind rise those pleasing lines :-
Not in the proud cathedral where splendid thousands throng, Not in the faint and formal plaint the loud thanksgiving song. But alone, alone with Nature on the everlasting hills.

It is astonishment which takes possession of our being in the first instance as we recognise that here a centre surrounded by historical interest, the very air we breathe is laded with mysticism. And we are filled with desire to penetrate the meanings of the early works of man, and learn something of their mystery.

Climbing of any sort is arduous enough in Egypt, and it was a fervent Deo Gratias that signalled our arrival on the summit. Some thinking soul, having anticipated future needs, had erected a crude seat of stone upon which we rested, and, below, Cairo lay like an open book waiting to he read. We are interested at the sight of countless minarets- those religious sentinels and become absorbed as the flood of time which rushed through our mind leaves in its wake the thoughts, that here in the cradle of philosophy Moses, Pythagoras, and Plato exhausted the earliest supplies of learning, and that Abraham, and Herodotus looked in no less wonder than we have often done at the weird triangular shapes now enveloped in an old gold mist. How majestic those eternal monuments look in the fading light. Yet they have no beauty, but as we are appalled by their tremendous size the truth of the old axiom becomes apparent "that in vastness, whatever be its nature, there dwell the true elements of sublimity."
Those mighty piles, the Pyramids have over lived The feeble generations of mankind.
What though unmoved they bore the deluge weight.
Survivors of the ruined world?
Whit though the fonder filled with miracles
And wealth miraculous their ample vaults?

The ruthless hand of the archaeologist has disturbed the wealth miraculous, and even the founders have been subjected to a rude resurrection, and repose, as Mycerinus does in the British Museum to satisfy the curiosity of a vulgar eve; It is the "folly of the wise." If these men had been less infinite in their precautions their bodies might yet be where their fellows laid them vanitatas vanitateur. Was Gautier right, when he wrote "pour moi le monde visible existe"? At the moment we feel he was not After all it is the unseen that speaks to us here, for the voice of Nature calls. It would be a soulless man indeed who could remain unmoved at this picture, in the rich, and sacred valley of the Nile the palms with oriental charm and grace respond to the whisperings of a breeze, and the Nile, a liquid strip, breaks the green until the vision is outlived. No sound reaches us save the hum from a distant world. The sun, a blazing hall, reflects its lustre West to East. A few clouds, in their temerity, have approached too near as if to mar the beauty of these trial moments, but have welted into liquid gold against the opaque turquoise.

The painter's brush, or writer's pen would he futile in endeavouring to reproduce what nature offers here. It is for the eye to see, and the heart to feel, for "the best part of beauty is that which a picture connot express." We succumb to the influences of the unseen. Call it the soul of nature if you will, or some occult power playing with fantastic force upon the human mind. To us it is the Creator's art the dying sun's triumph, holding out a promise of immortality.
ARTHUR S. DELANY.

div.head: A BUMPER CORN YEAR.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent).
Larnaca 17th May, 1907.

Sunshine and rain have alternated during the present month, and for the ordinarily constituted individual the weather has been quite delightful. The farmers and market gardeners too have reason to rejoice, for, except for a few instances of laid corn, the refreshing rains have been beneficial both to cattle and crops.

There seems to be no doubt that this will be a bumper corn year, One sure indication is the unprecedented demand for reaping machines. Cyprus is slowly waking up to the fact that she may, with advantage to herself and without loss of dignity, imitate the example of all other agricultural and progressive countries, and utilize those labour-saving machines which are now so familiar elsewhere. Their introduction, hitherto very gradual, has received a welcome impetus this year owing to the combination of heavy crops and high wages. No amount of argument or demonstration could so effectively bring home to the Cypriot agriculturist the advantages of a reaping machine as the stubborn fact which now confronts him that harvest daily wages are now in many instances 2/4 1/2 c.piastres for men and 1/5 c.piastres for women, and in some cases even higher. No wonder that many a farmer who, some four or five years ago, grumbled at having to pay 10 or 11 piastrès per day for harvestmen now finds he can save from his harvest wage bill more than enough to pay the price of a reaper in one year.

A valuable fuel ground has, during the last two years been established at Athalassa, near Nicosia. From here, at no distant period, a supply of fire wood should be available which will prove most acceptable to the inhabitants of that town Many thousand trees—eucalyptus, acacias, cypress, easuarinas and others—have been planted there by the Forest Department and remarkably healthy they look, They have encroached largely on the land originally intended to serve as an experimental farm, and for which object the property was originally acquired ; but some fine crops of imported wheat and barley are now being reaped, the selected grain from which will, presumably, be available for distribution amongst native farmers.

Much stir has been created in this town by the discovery of irregularities at the Post Office. Several members of the staff have been suspended from their duties, and further proceedings are expected to bo instituted.

The Cyprus Amateur Dramatic Society gave their second private performance on the 15th instant at Nicosia, at the residence of one of their members, kindly lent for the occasion, and we hear that the entertainment was in every way most enjoyable and successful. The Society may be said to have already justified its existence, and it is giving a further proof of its usefulness in developing musical and dramatic talent by contributing the services of several of its members to a performance which is announced to be geld on the 23rd instant at the Papadopoulo Theatre, Nicosia, in aid of funds towards a consumptive hospital which it is desired to form.
A sharp thunderstorm broke over Nicosia on the 15th instant, about midday. A tree near Government House was struck by lightening and fell through one of the windows of the building.

Mr. Hens Holmboe of Christiana, who visited this Island some eighteen months ago on behalf on the University of Christiana, to investigate the flora of the country, has just been appointed Director of the Museum at Bergen. He is engaged in compiling a book giving the results of his researches and discoveries.

A large number of departures took place by the mail boat last week. General Sir Robert Biddulph, Mr. J.C. Macaskie and the Misses Macaskie, Mr. and Mrs. Hatton Richards, Miss Parker, Mr. and Mrs, Otto Holbach were among the passengers.

The English community at Nicosia is, as usual, profiting by the delightful spring weather and long days, and tennis, croquet and golf tournaments are in full swing. Officials at the capital have certainly the advantage in this respect over their colleagues in the districts, who are too few in number to do much in the way of games.

div.head: PALESTINE EXHIBITION IN LONDON.
div.p: Great progress is being made with the preparations for the Palestine, in London Exhibition, which will be held from June 11 to July 2. The Royal Agricultural Hall, Islington, will he filled with the largest collection of exhibits and models relating to Bible lands ever seen in this or any other country. The tabernacle is to be strictly in accordance with original measurements, and will, no doubt, attract Jews as well Christians. The altars, as well as the Sacred Ark, the various vessels, etc., will all be of the dimensions recorded in the Bible.

An important exhibit will be a gigantic raised map of Palestine, which will be 60ft. long, and will occupy 1800 square feet of space. Other models of general interest will be the city of Jerusalem as it must have appeared in the days of out Lord. This model is made of wood, and is said to be constructed of about a million pieces. Modern Jerusalem, the glorious Second Temple, and a facsimile of the "Garden Tomb." will also prove attractive. Of Eastern life there to be an endless variety. The exhibition is being held under the auspices of the London Society for Promoting Christianity amongst the Jews.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: CRICKET
RAILWAY INSTITUTE
VERSUS
"C" SQDN. 6TH INNISKILLING DRAGS.

This match took place on the Institute ground on Friday. The homo captain having won the toss took first knock. Rev. Burns and Windsor went in first as usual. With only 7 scored the latter was well caught at square leg and Attwood the next man was stumped at the same total. Three wicket were down for 22 but Walker and Rev. Burns made a good stand and 40 were added before the former was given out to a doubtful "caught and bowled." Davies, the Institute captain, then made 15 in good style. He and Rev. Bums were then out in quick succession. The latter played very well for his score of 29 The tail end of the side added 20, the innings closing for 107. The Dragoons made a very poor start seven wickets falling for only 41 runs. Rudge and Draper were the only men to make any resistance. Nine wickets were down for 48 when Gregson and Scarborough became partners, but these two hit in lively fashion and the total had reached 68 before Wilson bowled Scarbrough. Wilson and Rev. Bunts, who took 5 for 39 and 5 for 27 respect ively, bowled extremely well. The following are the details of scores :—

div.head: LES BANQUES ET LA CRISE ACTUELLE.
div.p: Sur l'initiative de M. R. Suarès et de concert avec les personnalités financières les plus influentes, une entente intervint en Avril dernier entre reporteurs, agents de change et banquiers. Sur la foi du concours de ces derniers, les reporteurs ont accordé les 5 mois de délai demandés au taux de 7 à 9% et les Agents de change ont payé les compensations pour tous leurs clients. Or, dit M. S. C. Deville, dans le "Journal du Caire" il est avéré aujourd'hui qu'au lieu du concours promis, certaines banques font ce qu'elles peuvent pour aggraver la situation.

Certains établissements, dont les caisses regorgent d'or, refusent la moindre avance sur des titres de tout repos comme ceux de la Banque Agricole, de la Banque Nationale et du Crédit Foncier; les uns répandent sur l'état de la place des bruits pessimistes et tendancieux ; d'autres empêchent les acheteurs, qui seraient peut-être plus nombreux qu'on ne pense, de donner leurs ordres, en leur, promettant des cours encore plus bas.

Cette attitude est absolument déplorable et peut avoir les plus fâcheuses conséquences pour la fortune publique, pour l'avenir de l'Egypte et pour les provocateurs eux mêmes qui seraient sinon les premières, du moins les secondes victimes.

La conduite des banques d'Egypte contraste étrangement avec celle des banques qui ont su relever eu quelques semaines des places comme New-York, autrement - malades que celles du Caire et d'Alexandrie, et elle est d'autant plus injuste et incompréhensible que nos établissements de crédit se sont rendus eu grande partie responsables de la crise, en nous inondant d'une quantité de titres hors de proportion avec nos moyens d'assimilation et en présentant eux-inèmes l'appat aux victimes qu'ils étranglent aujourd'hui.

En patronant les émissions, les Banques ont fourni un ample aliment à la spéculation dont elles se plaignent ; elles les ont encouragées en prêtant aux souscripteurs tout l'argent nécessaire pour les couvrir un grand nombre de fois et elles ont d'ailleurs encaissé de ce chef dé grasses commissions, tout en prêtant leur or à gros intérêts.

Les sociétés nouvelles, lancées, patronées et trouvées très bommes par les Banques au moment de leur émission, ne sont pas devenues plus mauvaises aurourd'hui ; la très grande majorité de nos anciennes valeurs est digne de la plus haute confiance ; un grand nombre de nos Sociétés ont fait leurs preuves et distribuent chaque année des dividendes élevés ; les forces vitales du pays sont intactes ; les causes de sa prospérité, le Nil, la fertilité de son sol et la culture du coton ne sont en rien compromis ; une sage et habile administration en assure la permanence.
Les Banques ne peuvent ignorer tout cela.

Leur developpement extraordinaire en nombre et en capitaux prouve leur confiance dans l'avenir de l'Egypte et si, en dépit de cette confiance, elles refusent tout crédit, tout escompte, toute avance sur des titres qu'elles savent cotés bien au dessous de leur valeur ; si elles préfèrent garder leur or improductif plutôt que de le placer à un intérêt élevé et avec moins de risques que lorsque la cote est à son maximum ; si, au lieu de rendre la confiance, à tous les travailleurs, elles préfèrent les décourager ; si, non pas seulement par leur passivité, mais encore par leur hostilité, elles cherchent à annihiler les efforts admirables qui nous ont préservés jusqu'iei, c'est parce qu'elles spéculent sur le malheur public, c'est parce qu'elles obiéissent a un mot d'ordre et tendent vers un objectif exactement contraire a celui qui inspirait au-mois d'avril dernier M. Raphael Suarès et ses collègues du Conseil de la Banque Nationale.

Des influences moins généreuses ont prédominé dans le consortium des nécrophages du marché et, sous le prétexte fallacieux d'assainissement et de prudence, une ande noire prépare dans l'ombre l'étrangleniént et le déimuillcmeiit de tous les faibles.

div.head: The Cairo Exchange Limited.

p.hi: Every applicant for Ordinary Shares will be entitled to apply for and receive an allotment of one Founder's Share for every fifty Ordinary Shares allotted to him.
This Prospectus has been filed with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies. The Subscription List will open on the 22nd day of May 1907, and close on or before the 23rd day of May 1907.
Divided into 123,750 Ordinary Shares of £1 each, and 25,000 Founders Shares of One Shilling each.

div.p: The Ordinary Shares are entitled to receive out of the divisible profits of each year after providing for reserve and for the remuneration of the Managing Director a preferential dividend at the rate of Five per cent.

The balance of such profits after providing for the remuneration of the Directors as hereunder mentioned will be attributed as to 60 per cent thereof to the Ordinary Shares and as to 40 percent thereof to the Founders Shares.
The Founders Shares are also entitled to 40 per cent of the surplus assets which in the winding up of the Company shall remain after repayment of Capital.
No underwriting Commission has been or will be paid.
98,750 Ordinary Shares are now offered for subscription at par together with the corresponding number of Founders Shares in the proportion slated above.
Tho Ordinary Shares are payable as follows :
And the balance in calls not exceeding 5/- per Share, the first call not to be made before the expiration of four months from the date of issue.

p.hi: The Founders Shares are payable in full on Application.

div.p: No allotment of less than 50 Ordinary Shares will be made to any one Subscriber.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: This Company has been formed with the objects set forth in its Memorandum of Association and in particular for the purpose of acquiring as a going concern the business of Stockbrokers and Agents de Change heretofore carried on by Mr. Percy Wyfold Stout in partnership with the late Mr. Ernest Charles Hogg under the style of Hogg & Stout.

Under the Contract below mentioned the business of the Firm will he taken over by the Company as from the 2nd day of April 1907 (the date of the death of Mr. Hogg) from which date the whole of the Firm's assets will he acquired and its liabilities as sumed by the Company. The price to be paid for the Goodwill of the business is £25,000 which will be satisfied by the allotment to Mr. Percy Wyfold Stout, the surviving partner in the Firm, of 25,000 Ordinary Shares credited as fully paid.

The Company will acquire the assets of the Firm including all cash in hand stocks shares and securities bookdebts contracts in course of execution leasehold pre mises and furniture and effects in consideration of the payment in cash to Mr. Percy Wyfold Stout of the sum of £.E.29,480 that being the amount certified by Mr. Kerr, Chartered Accountant, as the fair value of the excess of the assets over liabilities as on the 2nd April 1907.
Mr. Percy Wyfold Stout has agreed to act as Managing Director of the Company for a period of five years upon the terms of the Contracts below mentioned.

Mr. Stout has agreed to pay all the preliminary expenses of forming and floating the Company down to, but not including, the first general allotment of Ordinary Shares to the public, such preliminary expenses being estimated at £2,000—. He has also guaranteed the subscription of 50,000 Ordinary Shares now offered in consideration of his having the right at any time prior to the 31st December 1907 to call for the allotment to him at par of 14,500 Founders Shares and for the allotment at par either to himself or his nominees of the additional number of 4,425 Founders Shares.

Col. Gordon and Mr. Russell, the other Directors of the Company are subscribing for and will each be allotted at par 400 Founders' Shares. Each of them has also sub underwritten 2,000 Ordinary Shares in consideration of the right to subscribe for 120 additional Founders' Shares.
The Minimum subscription on which the Directors may proceed to allotment is 25 per cent of the shares offered.
The following Contracts have been entered into :

1. A Contract dated the 9th May 1907 between the Vendor, Percy Wyfold Stout, carrying on business as a Stockbroker at Cairo under the style or firm of Hogg Stout of the one part, and the Company of the other part, being the Contract for Sale.
2. A Contract dated the 9th May 1907, between the Company of the one part, and the said Percy Wyfold Stout of the other part, being a Contract for the employment of the latter as Managing Director.
This Contract contains the following provisions :

1. The said Percy Wyfold Stout (hereinafter called the Managing Director) shall be entitled to hold office as Managing Director of the Company for a term of five years from the time when the Company shall become entitled to commence business.
2. The Managing Director whilst holding such office shall perform the duties and exercise the powers which from time to time may be assigned to or vested in him by the Directors of the Company.
3. So long as the Managing Director shall bold such office, no other Director or Directors of the Company snail he appointed without the consent of such Managing Director.

4. The Managing Director whilst holding such office shall well and faithfully serve the Company and use his best endeavours to promote the interests thereof. He shall be entitled to four consecutive calendar months' leave of absence in every year at a time convenient to him.

5. The Managing Director whilst holding such office shall hold his Membership of the Cairo Bourse lor the benefit of the Company, and shall use his best endeavours to continue such Membership, and shall not operate on the said Bourse except on behalf of the Company.

6. The Managing Director whilst holding such office shall be paid as remuneration for his services a fixed salary at the rate of £1,500 pet annum payable monthly, and in addition thereto shall be entitled to receive in respect of every year such sum (not exceeding £5,000) as shall be equivalent to two and a half per cent of the profits of the Company made during the financial year or other period comprised in the accounts submitted to the Ordinary General Meeting in each year and of any profits carried forward from past years. The Managing Director whilst holding such office shall not be entitled to participate in the remuneration allowed by the Articles of Association to the Directors of the Company.

3. A Contract dated the 9th May 1907 made between the said Percy Wyfold Stout of the one part and the Company of the other part being the Contract guaranteeing the subscription of the Ordinary Shares now offered.
The following are extracts from the Company's Articles of Association.

85. The qualification of a Director shall be the holding of Ordinary Shares of the Company to the nominal value of £500. A first Director may act before acquiring his qualification, but shall in any case acquire the same within one month from his appointment, and unless he shall do so he shall be deemed to have agreed to take the said shares from the Company and the same shall be forthwith allotted to him accordingly

87. As remuneration for their services each Director shall be paid a fixed salary at the rate of £150 per annum, and such further sums as the Company in General Meeting may from time to time determine And the Directors shall also be paid collectively the additional remuneration profits hereinafter mentioned, and such remuneration shall be divided among them in such proportions and manner as they may determine, and in default of such determination equally.

98. The Directors for the time being may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to he a Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company, and on such terms and conditions as they think fit The said Percy Wyfold Stout shall if nominated as Director by the subscribers hereto he the Managing Director of the Company, and is hereinafter referred to as " the first Managing Director. "

101. The remuneration of a Managing Director shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors, and may be by way of salary or commission, or participation in profits, or by any or all of those modes. A Managing Director shall not, unless otherwise determined, be entitled to remuneration as a Director.

109. If any of the Directors shall be called upon to perform extra services for any of the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate the Director or Directors in such manner as may be determined by the Directors.

114. The Directors may from time to time provide for the management of the affairs of the Company in any special locality in any part of the world in such manner as they think fit, and the provisions contained in the six next following clauses shall be without prejudice to the general powers conferred by this paragraph :—

(1) The Directors from to time and at any time may establish any local boards or agencies for advising the Directors as to the conduct of the Company's business or for managing any of the affairs of the Company in any specified locality in any part of the world, and may appoint any person to be members of such local board, or any managers or agents, and may fix their remuneration.

118. The profits of the Company made during the financial year or other period comprised in the accounts submitted to the Ordinary General Meeting in each year, with any profits carried forward from past years, shall he applicable in order of priority and manner following :—

(1) Five per cent of such profits shall be carried to a Reserve Fund to he established pursuant to clause 116 hereof, whilst and whenever such Reserve Fund shall amount to less than 25 per cent of the paid-up capital of the Company ; and two and one half per cent of such profits, but not exceeding £5,000 in any one year, shall be paid to the first Managing Director whilst holding such office as additional remuneration for his services.
(2) There shall next be paid thereout a preferential dividend for such period at the rate of five per cent per annum on the capital paid up or credited as paid up on the Ordinary Shares.
(3) There shall next be paid thereout to the Directors, as additional remuneration for their services, a sum equivalent to ten per cent thereof, but not exceeding £5,000.

(4) The balance of such profits shall, as to 60 per cent thereof, be applicable to the payment of a further dividend on. the capital paid up on the Ordinary Shares, and as to 40 per cent thereof shall be divided rateably among the holders of the Founders Shares.
Copies of the Memorandum and Articles of Association, and of the above mentioned Contracts can be inspected at the offices of the Legal Advisers at any time during business hours.
A copy of the Company's Memorandum of Association is printed in the fold of this Prospectus and forms part of it.
Applications for Shares should be made upon the forms accompanying the Prospectus, and sent to the Anglo-Egyptian Bank in Cairo or to the Secretary in London, together with the amount of the deposit.

Where no allotment is made the deposit will be returned in full, and where the number of shares allotted is less than the number applied for, the balance of the deposit will be applied towards the remaining payments.
Failure to pay any instalments on Shares allotted when due will render previous payments liable to forfeiture.
Cairo, 18th May I907. 30292-3-2
